posts.name: Ben Edwards
posts.cooked:
I’ve seen far too many posts and pictures of robots with burnt out motors on intakes and broken arm drive chains… For those who still have time, I highly recommend adding torque limiters. There are two types we used this year which saved our poor arm and claw MULTIPLE times when our driver smacked the arm into things.

The cheap low torque method: Take a pulley or sprocket and drill it out to 9/16". This is easier with a round pilot hole but doable even for a hex bore, if you’re careful.  Clamp it between two hex shaft collars on a Thunderhex (or eq) shaft, with a bolt+washers threaded on the end to provide more clamping force.  The sprocket/pulley will slip between the shaft collars when too much torque is applied, saving your gearbox.  This is only good up to about 10 ft-lbs or so and isn’t super precise but works well for light wrist joints or intake drives.

The McMaster torque limiter: This works best if you’re already using #35 chain.  Order one of these suckers: McMaster-Carr and one of these: McMaster-Carr and either broach it to 1/2" hex shaft, or get one of these from Andymark: https://www.andymark.com/products/super-shifter-wheel-shaft which fits in the 1/2" round hole of the McMaster part and can be easily adapted to a MaxPlanetary or other gearbox.  You’ll need a shaft key too. These are good up to 60 ft-lbs which works great for the gearbox end of the chain reduction for your arm pivot.  The limit point is easily adjustable and repeatable.

These things save arms and motors.  They can mean the difference between a broken, unusable manipulator and one that takes a hit and keeps moving. To see them in action watch us (6500) in FNC Wake County playoff match 5, at about the 50 second mark our claw hit the substation hard and tilted down - and we just rotated it back up and kept going.  We didn’t have the arm or claw geared fast enough, nor enough drive practice, but those torque limiters kept us going.

BTW edited - We didn’t invent either of these, the clamp shaft collar one is from the Everybot a few years ago Team 2177: ( Is it worth it to have a retractable intake powered by pneumatics if pneumatics won't serve any other purpose? - #17 by Jon_Stratis ) and of course the McMaster torque limiter is a COTS product.  Spreading awareness!

link_counts.title: Is it worth it to have a retractable intake powered by pneumatics if pneumatics won't serve any other purpose?

posts.name: Jon Stratis
posts.cooked:
beedward:

one is from the Everybot

Just an FYI - that particular design you linked isn’t Everybot - it’s a design my team came up with completely independently for last year’s robot, which was definitely not an Everybot.  It’s entirely possible Everybot has had something similar at some point, though!

posts.name: Ben Edwards
posts.cooked:
You’re quite right, I apologize.  Credit to 2177 for your awesome design!

The 2019 Everybot was the one I was thinking of, which uses a very similar setup (albeit with a Bosch seat motor) for its hatch panel manipulator.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: Don’t forget that current limiting is available on most FRC motor controllers.  This will definitely save your motors if used correctly, and will probably help save your mechanisms as well.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.custom_user_title: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: Ben Edwards
posts.cooked:
Current limit absolutely helps you if it’s the motor driving the mechanism, like on intakes or driving things into hard stops.

It doesn’t do much for you if it’s external forces doing the driving, when your alliance partner rams into you…  The motor will survive but the gearbox, chain, whatever maybe not.  Better to have a controlled weak point.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
It can help in that latter scenario too, if your gearing allows for backdriving.  Definitely won’t help if the external force is enough to break the mechanism against internal friction, though.

This is one reason I really don’t endorse worm drives on mechanisms subject to external forces.

posts.custom_user_title: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked:
beedward:

Better to have a controlled weak point.

I don’t recall where, but I have seen this referred to as a “mechanical fuse”.

posts.name: EricH
posts.cooked: In some applications, I prefer “self-destructing hardware”. It’s great when you need to preserve “stuff” in an application you know it won’t survive easily. (Nylon bolts come to mind.)

posts.name: Ari Meles-Braverman
posts.cooked: Another option is a flat/V belt or an under-tensioned timing belt. When the torque limit is exceeded, the belt just slips/skips. We used that this year on our intake to prevent jammed cubes from stalling the NEO.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FIRST Israel CSA, FRC 5987/5951 Technical Mentor

posts.custom_user_title: FIRST Israel CSA, FRC 5987/5951 Technical Mentor

posts.name: Ari Meles-Braverman
posts.cooked: Yes, but with the lifespan of these robots it’s not a problem if the belt is loose enough. Probably better to use a non-timing belt, but sometimes you just use what you have

posts.name: Mr V
posts.cooked: We’ve used round belting in the past too. We’ve never had enough wear to warrant replacement in 2 district events though we’ve always made and brought spares for those.
